elements.content: A three-dimensional (3D) metal–organic framework (MOF), namely, {[Mn4(PBA)4(H2O)6·5H2O]} n (Mn-PBA), has been successfully constructed from 5-(4-pyridin-3-yl-benzoylamino)-isophthalic acid ligand (H2PBA) and Mn­(II) ions under solvothermal condition. Structural analysis reveals that there exist 1D hexagonal channels in the 3D structure along the b-axis. Mesoporous Mn3O4/C composites were fabricated by the direct thermolysis of Mn-PBA at 500 °C under an air atmosphere. When tested as a lithium-ion battery anode material, the Mn3O4/C electrode delivers an excellent capacity of 1032 mAh g–1 at 200 mA g–1 after 500 cycles along with remarkable rate capacity, which is supposed to benefit from the unique microspheres characteristic and large accessible specific area. Owing to the good cycling stability and high capacity, the Mn3O4/C electrode can be regarded as a promising anode material for LIBs.
elements.clean_text: A three-dimensional (3D) metal-organic framework (MOF), namely, {[Mn4(PBA)4(H2O)6⋅5H2O]} n  (Mn-PBA), has been successfully constructed from 5-(4-pyridin-3-yl-benzoylamino)-isophthalic acid ligand (H2PBA) and Mn(II) ions under solvothermal condition. Structural analysis reveals that there exist 1D hexagonal channels in the 3D structure along the b-axis. Mesoporous Mn3O4/C composites were fabricated by the direct thermolysis of Mn-PBA at 500 °C under an air atmosphere. When tested as a lithium-ion battery anode material, the Mn3O4/C electrode delivers an excellent capacity of 1032 mAh g-1 at 200 mA g-1 after 500 cycles along with remarkable rate capacity, which is supposed to benefit from the unique microspheres characteristic and large accessible specific area. Owing to the good cycling stability and high capacity, the Mn3O4/C electrode can be regarded as a promising anode material for LIBs.

elements.content: Mesoporous Mn3O4/C micropheres were obtained by thermolysis of a Mn-PBA MOF as precursor under an air atmosphere and used as LIBs anode material. The results display that the Mn3O4/C electrode shows a high capacity of about 1032 mAh g−1 at 0.2 A g−1 after 500 cycles, together with the stable cycling behavior and good rate performance.
elements.clean_text: Mesoporous Mn3O4/C micropheres were obtained by thermolysis of a Mn-PBA MOF as precursor under an air atmosphere and used as LIBs anode material. The results display that the Mn3O4/C electrode shows a high capacity of about 1032 mAh g-1 at 0.2 A g-1 after 500 cycles, together with the stable cycling behavior and good rate performance.

elements.content: With the rapid progress of advanced electronic equipment, such as high-speed cameras, flexible telephones, portable laptop computers, and hybrid electric vehicles, it is necessary to develop high performance and high availability energy transformation systems. Lithium-ion batteries (LIBs) with cycling stability, light weight, and high energy density are regarded as promising, clean, and renewable energy sources. Nevertheless, because of the easy exfoliation, poor rate capacity and cycling stability, low theoretical capacity (372 mAh g–1), and inherent safety risk, commercial graphite material could not achieve the high power density goal of new-generation LIBs. In recent years, transition metal oxides (TMOs), such as Co3O4, Fe3O4, ZnO, CuO, and MnO, have been widely researched as anode materials for their satisfactory energy storage performances. Among various TMOs, Mn3O4 has attracted extensive attention owing to its low voltage potential (∼0.5 V vs Li+/Li), high theoretical capacity, low-cost, natural abundance, and environmental compatibility. However, the use of pure Mn3O4 is limited by large capacity loss arising from volume expansion during electrochemical reaction, low rate capability, and poor electrical conductivity (usually between 10–5 and 10–6 S m–1). In order to tackle these problems, various strategies have been developed. One effective method is to combine with diverse carbon-based materials, such as conducting polymer graphene, carbon nanowire, carbon tube, and carbon fibers, which are electronically conductive and lightweight. In addition, fabrication of a porous structure with large specific surface areas has also been regarded as an effective approach to improve the capacity retention by accommodating the volume change during Li-ion insertion/extraction, which can provide more reaction sites and enlarge contact areas between the electrolyte and active materials.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

With the rapid progress of advanced electronic equipment, such as high-speed cameras, flexible telephones, portable laptop computers, and hybrid electric vehicles, it is necessary to develop high performance and high availability energy transformation systems. Lithium-ion batteries (LIBs) with cycling stability, light weight, and high energy density are regarded as promising, clean, and renewable energy sources. Nevertheless, because of the easy exfoliation, poor rate capacity and cycling stability, low theoretical capacity (372 mAh g-1), and inherent safety risk, commercial graphite material could not achieve the high power density goal of new-generation LIBs. In recent years, transition metal oxides (TMOs), such as Co3O4, Fe3O4, ZnO, CuO, and MnO, have been widely researched as anode materials for their satisfactory energy storage performances. Among various TMOs, Mn3O4 has attracted extensive attention owing to its low voltage potential (~0.5 V vs Li+/Li), high theoretical capacity, low-cost, natural abundance, and environmental compatibility. However, the use of pure Mn3O4 is limited by large capacity loss arising from volume expansion during electrochemical reaction, low rate capability, and poor electrical conductivity (usually between 10-5 and 10-6 S m-1). In order to tackle these problems, various strategies have been developed. One effective method is to combine with diverse carbon-based materials, such as conducting polymer graphene, carbon nanowire, carbon tube, and carbon fibers, which are electronically conductive and lightweight. In addition, fabrication of a porous structure with large specific surface areas has also been regarded as an effective approach to improve the capacity retention by accommodating the volume change during Li-ion insertion/extraction, which can provide more reaction sites and enlarge contact areas between the electrolyte and active materials.

elements.content: Particularly, metal–organic frameworks (MOFs), constructed from organic ligands and metal ions or metal clusters, are emerging as a porous organic–inorganic hybrid material with tunable porosities and large surface areas. In recent years, MOFs have been used as either precursors or templates to form metal oxides and carbon materials via thermal treatment. Despite these great successes, it still remains a significant challenge to develop promising electrode materials with reversible and maximum lithium storage. In our previous work, we had synthesized a Pb-MOF, in which the organic moiety could provide probable Li+ binding sites for the reversible lithium storage. By utilizing a new Cd-MOF as template, porous carbon with a microtube shape was fabricated and delivered a discharge capacity of 741 mAg h–1 at 100 mA g–1. As a continuation of our work, herein, we used a linear ligand 5-(4-pyridin-3-yl-benzoylamino)-iso­phthalic acid (H2­PBA) to construct a porous Mn-based MOF. Delightedly, a well-ordered crystalline 3D porous Mn-PBA was successfully synthesized and then was transformed into porous Mn3O4/C composites by annealing under an air atmosphere. Furthermore, we also evaluated the electrochemical performances as an anode material for LIBs.
elements.clean_text: Particularly, metal-organic frameworks (MOFs), constructed from organic ligands and metal ions or metal clusters, are emerging as a porous organic-inorganic hybrid material with tunable porosities and large surface areas. In recent years, MOFs have been used as either precursors or templates to form metal oxides and carbon materials via thermal treatment. Despite these great successes, it still remains a significant challenge to develop promising electrode materials with reversible and maximum lithium storage. In our previous work, we had synthesized a Pb-MOF, in which the organic moiety could provide probable Li+ binding sites for the reversible lithium storage. By utilizing a new Cd-MOF as template, porous carbon with a microtube shape was fabricated and delivered a discharge capacity of 741 mAg h-1 at 100 mA g-1. As a continuation of our work, herein, we used a linear ligand 5-(4-pyridin-3-yl-benzoylamino)-isophthalic acid (H2PBA) to construct a porous Mn-based MOF. Delightedly, a well-ordered crystalline 3D porous Mn-PBA was successfully synthesized and then was transformed into porous Mn3O4/C composites by annealing under an air atmosphere. Furthermore, we also evaluated the electrochemical performances as an anode material for LIBs.

elements.content: Functional groups of the materials were assessed using Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (Thermo Nicolet NEXUS 670 FT-IR, USA). Elemental analyses were performed using a PerkinElmer 240 elemental analyzer (USA). The crystalline phase was identified by a Bruker D8 Advance X-ray diffraction patterns diffractometer (BRUKER-AXS, Germany) equipped with a Cu target tube and a graphite monochromator. Raman spectra were obtained from a Renishaw inVia confocal Raman microscope (U.K.). A Netzsch Thermo Microbalance TG 209 F1 Libra (Germany) was used for thermogravimetric analyses (TGA) in order to know the thermal behavior (mass) of the material. The sorption isotherms were assessed using a Belsorp max gas sorption analyzer (Japan) at 77 K. The surface morphology and architecture were recorded using field emission scanning electron microscopy (FESEM, TESCAN Maia 3, Czech). X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was recorded by an ESCALAB 250Xi XPS spectrometer (USA). A Varian Mercury Plus 300 MHz spectrometer was used to record 1H NMR spectra (USA).
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials Characterization

Functional groups of the materials were assessed using Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (Thermo Nicolet NEXUS 670 FT-IR, USA). Elemental analyses were performed using a PerkinElmer 240 elemental analyzer (USA). The crystalline phase was identified by a Bruker D8 Advance X-ray diffraction patterns diffractometer (BRUKER-AXS, Germany) equipped with a Cu target tube and a graphite monochromator. Raman spectra were obtained from a Renishaw inVia confocal Raman microscope (U.K.). A Netzsch Thermo Microbalance TG 209 F1 Libra (Germany) was used for thermogravimetric analyses (TGA) in order to know the thermal behavior (mass) of the material. The sorption isotherms were assessed using a Belsorp max gas sorption analyzer (Japan) at 77 K. The surface morphology and architecture were recorded using field emission scanning electron microscopy (FESEM, TESCAN Maia 3, Czech). X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was recorded by an ESCALAB 250Xi XPS spectrometer (USA). A Varian Mercury Plus 300 MHz spectrometer was used to record 1H NMR spectra (USA).

elements.content: The synthetic route of the H2PBA ligand is given in Figure S1, and the obtained ligand was further confirmed by H1 NMR spectrum (Figure S2). A mixture containing H2PBA (72.4 mg, 0.2 mmol), Mn­(NO3)2·6H2O (112 mg, 0.4 mmol), H2O (12 mL), and dimethylformamide (12 mL) was sealed in a glass reaction bottle. The system was heated at 100 °C for 3 days and then cooled to room temperature. Pale yellow crystals were obtained by filtration and washed with DMF. FT-IR (KBr, cm–1): 3266 (m), 2373 (w), 2036 (w), 1616 (vs), 1548 (w), 1394 (w), 904 (w), 617 (vs) (see Figure S3). Anal. Calcd for C80H78­N8O31Mn4 (1867.26): C 51.49, H 4.18, N 5.99%; found: C 51.43, H 4.22, N 5.97%.
elements.clean_text:
Preparation of the Mn-PBA

The synthetic route of the H2PBA ligand is given in Figure S1, and the obtained ligand was further confirmed by H1 NMR spectrum (Figure S2). A mixture containing H2PBA (72.4 mg, 0.2 mmol), Mn(NO3)2⋅6H2O (112 mg, 0.4 mmol), H2O (12 mL), and dimethylformamide (12 mL) was sealed in a glass reaction bottle. The system was heated at 100 °C for 3 days and then cooled to room temperature. Pale yellow crystals were obtained by filtration and washed with DMF. FT-IR (KBr, cm-1): 3266 (m), 2373 (w), 2036 (w), 1616 (vs), 1548 (w), 1394 (w), 904 (w), 617 (vs) (see Figure S3). Anal. Calcd for C80H78N8O31Mn4 (1867.26): C 51.49, H 4.18, N 5.99%; found: C 51.43, H 4.22, N 5.97%.

elements.content: The as-prepared Mn-PBA samples were calcined directly in a tubular furnace at 500 °C under an air atmosphere for 5 h. The resulting products were obtained after 3 h and then washed with anhydrous methanol and deionized water before drying in an oven at 100 °C to obtain the final products.
elements.clean_text:
Preparation of Mn3O4/C Material

The as-prepared Mn-PBA samples were calcined directly in a tubular furnace at 500 °C under an air atmosphere for 5 h. The resulting products were obtained after 3 h and then washed with anhydrous methanol and deionized water before drying in an oven at 100 °C to obtain the final products.

elements.content: The as-made Mn-PBA samples were thermally treated at 700 °C in a nitrogen atmosphere. Subsequently, the obtained sample were washed with HF acid for 3 days to remove metal composite and dried under vacuum to generate the carbon material.
elements.clean_text:
Preparation of Carbon Material

The as-made Mn-PBA samples were thermally treated at 700 °C in a nitrogen atmosphere. Subsequently, the obtained sample were washed with HF acid for 3 days to remove metal composite and dried under vacuum to generate the carbon material.

elements.content: The working electrode was composed of the active material (70 wt %), acetylene black (20 wt %), and polyvinylidene difluoride (PVDF) (10 wt %) dissolved in N-methylpyrrolidinone (NMP). Each constituent was milled well to form a slurry that was pressed onto a cleaned copper foil current collector and dried at 100 °C for 12 h under vacuum. The loading amount of the active material on the area was about 1 mg cm–2. Electrochemical test CR2025-type coin cells were prepared in an Ar-filled glovebox (<0.01 ppm) using a porous polypropylene membrane (Celgard-2400) as the separate, lithium metal foil (Tianjin Lithium Industry Co., Ltd.) as the counter/reference electrodes, and 1.0 M LiPF6 in mixed ethyl methyl carbonate (EMC), diethyl carbonate (DEC), and ethylene carbonate (EC) (EMC:DEC:EC, 1:1:1 v/v/v) as the electrolyte. The galvanostatic charge/discharge tests were carried out at a current density of 200 mA g–1 at room temperature (25 °C) via a multichannel LAND CT2001 test system (Nanjing, China) between 0.01 and 3.0 V (vs Li+/Li). Cyclic voltammetry (CV) curves were performed using a CHI605C electrochemical workstation at a scanning rate of 0.1 mV s–1 (voltage range: 0.01–3.0 V). The electrochemical impedance spectra (EIS) were tested on the same workstation for various electrodes at 25 °C over the frequency range from 100 kHz to 0.01 Hz.
elements.clean_text:
Electrochemical Measurements

The working electrode was composed of the active material (70 wt %), acetylene black (20 wt %), and polyvinylidene difluoride (PVDF) (10 wt %) dissolved in N-methylpyrrolidinone (NMP). Each constituent was milled well to form a slurry that was pressed onto a cleaned copper foil current collector and dried at 100 °C for 12 h under vacuum. The loading amount of the active material on the area was about 1 mg cm-2. Electrochemical test CR2025-type coin cells were prepared in an Ar-filled glovebox (<0.01 ppm) using a porous polypropylene membrane (Celgard-2400) as the separate, lithium metal foil (Tianjin Lithium Industry Co., Ltd.) as the counter/reference electrodes, and 1.0 M LiPF6 in mixed ethyl methyl carbonate (EMC), diethyl carbonate (DEC), and ethylene carbonate (EC) (EMC:DEC:EC, 1:1:1 v/v/v) as the electrolyte. The galvanostatic charge/discharge tests were carried out at a current density of 200 mA g-1 at room temperature (25 °C) via a multichannel LAND CT2001 test system (Nanjing, China) between 0.01 and 3.0 V (vs Li+/Li). Cyclic voltammetry (CV) curves were performed using a CHI605C electrochemical workstation at a scanning rate of 0.1 mV s-1 (voltage range: 0.01-3.0 V). The electrochemical impedance spectra (EIS) were tested on the same workstation for various electrodes at 25 °C over the frequency range from 100 kHz to 0.01 Hz.

elements.content: X-ray reflection intensities were performed with a Bruker APEX II diffractometer at 296 K using graphite monochromatic Mo–Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å). The empirical absorption corrections were used to correct the reflections. The structure was solved by the direct method and refined by full-matrix least-squares on F 2 using SHELXL programs (SHELXTL-2016). The isotropic displacement parameter was used to place the organic hydrogen atoms in calculated positions. The details of data collection, crystal parameters, and refinement are summarized in Table S1. Table S2 presents the selected bond lengths and bond angles. CCDC 1536622 contains the supplementary crystallographic data.
elements.clean_text:
X-ray Crystallographic Studies

X-ray reflection intensities were performed with a Bruker APEX II diffractometer at 296 K using graphite monochromatic Mo-Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å). The empirical absorption corrections were used to correct the reflections. The structure was solved by the direct method and refined by full-matrix least-squares on F 2 using SHELXL programs (SHELXTL-2016). The isotropic displacement parameter was used to place the organic hydrogen atoms in calculated positions. The details of data collection, crystal parameters, and refinement are summarized in Table S1. Table S2 presents the selected bond lengths and bond angles. CCDC 1536622 contains the supplementary crystallographic data.

elements.content: Structural analysis displays that Mn-MOF crystallizes in monoclinic C2/c space group and the asymmetric unit contains two Mn2+ ions, two PBA2– ligands, three coordinated H2O molecules, and two and a half free H2O molecules. As depicted in a, the Mn(1) atom is coordinated by one N atom, three O atoms from four different PBA2– ligands, and one O atom from a water molecule. Mn(2) is also five coordinated in a distorted square pyramidal geometry. The basal plane is defined by one nitrogen atom (N1), one oxygen atom from a H2O molecule, and two carboxylate oxygen atoms from two different ligands, and the apical position is occupied by one oxygen atom from a H2O molecule. As seen in b, the neighboring Mn­(II) ions are connected together through the carboxylate groups of PBA2– ligands to form a 1D gridlike chain. These organic chains are further linked by PBA2– ligands using the two carboxylate groups with bidentate bridging coordination mode to give rise to a 3D framework (c). This 3D structure possesses 1D hexagonal channels along the b-axis (d). These channels are occupied by solvent molecules, giving a solvent accessible volume of approximately 19.7% (1610.1 Å3 of the 8162.06 Å3 unit cell volume), calculated by using the PLATON/SOL program.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Structure and Characterization of Mn-PBA MOF

Structural analysis displays that Mn-MOF crystallizes in monoclinic C2/c space group and the asymmetric unit contains two Mn2+ ions, two PBA2- ligands, three coordinated H2O molecules, and two and a half free H2O molecules. As depicted in a, the Mn(1) atom is coordinated by one N atom, three O atoms from four different PBA2- ligands, and one O atom from a water molecule. Mn(2) is also five coordinated in a distorted square pyramidal geometry. The basal plane is defined by one nitrogen atom (N1), one oxygen atom from a H2O molecule, and two carboxylate oxygen atoms from two different ligands, and the apical position is occupied by one oxygen atom from a H2O molecule. As seen in b, the neighboring Mn(II) ions are connected together through the carboxylate groups of PBA2- ligands to form a 1D gridlike chain. These organic chains are further linked by PBA2- ligands using the two carboxylate groups with bidentate bridging coordination mode to give rise to a 3D framework (c). This 3D structure possesses 1D hexagonal channels along the b-axis (d). These channels are occupied by solvent molecules, giving a solvent accessible volume of approximately 19.7% (1610.1 Å3 of the 8162.06 Å3 unit cell volume), calculated by using the PLATON/SOL program.

elements.content: (a) Coordination environment of Mn atom. (b) 1D gridlike organic chain in Mn-PBA. (c) 3D framework with 1D channel viewed along the b-axis (the metal centers are highlighted using polyhedra). (d) 3D packing structure with 1D channel.
elements.clean_text: 1  (a) Coordination environment of Mn atom. (b) 1D gridlike organic chain in Mn-PBA. (c) 3D framework with 1D channel viewed along the b-axis (the metal centers are highlighted using polyhedra). (d) 3D packing structure with 1D channel.

elements.content: The power X-ray diffraction (PXRD) pattern of the as-prepared Mn-PBA is shown in Figure S4. Most of the peak positions in the as-made samples and simulated one are quite well matched, indicating phase purity of the bulk samples. The difference in diffraction intensity may be due to the preferred orientation effect of the powder particles. The infrared spectrum (IR) reveals the adsorption peak around 3266 cm–1 for Mn-PBA assigned to the v­(OH) vibrations of the H2O molecules. Strong peaks at 1616 and 1393 cm–1 corresponded to asymmetric and symmetric vibrations for carboxylate groups (Figure S5). Thermal stability of the Mn-PBA was also measured under an air atmosphere. The curve in Figure S6 shows three main mass losses. The first weight loss (exp. 4.86%) between 30 and 150 °C corresponds to the release of five free H2O molecules (calcd. 4.82%). The second weight loss (exp. 5.65%) in the range of 150–220 °C is ascribed to the loss of six coordinated H2O molecules (calcd. 5.78%). However, when the temperature exceeds 300 °C, a large weight loss appears, indicating that the framework has collapsed. According to the TGA result, Mn-PBA samples in our case were calcined at 500 °C by one-step thermal treatment under a flow of air to ensure the complete conversion of precursors to the final products.
elements.clean_text: The power X-ray diffraction (PXRD) pattern of the as-prepared Mn-PBA is shown in Figure S4. Most of the peak positions in the as-made samples and simulated one are quite well matched, indicating phase purity of the bulk samples. The difference in diffraction intensity may be due to the preferred orientation effect of the powder particles. The infrared spectrum (IR) reveals the adsorption peak around 3266 cm-1 for Mn-PBA assigned to the v(OH) vibrations of the H2O molecules. Strong peaks at 1616 and 1393 cm-1 corresponded to asymmetric and symmetric vibrations for carboxylate groups (Figure S5). Thermal stability of the Mn-PBA was also measured under an air atmosphere. The curve in Figure S6 shows three main mass losses. The first weight loss (exp. 4.86%) between 30 and 150 °C corresponds to the release of five free H2O molecules (calcd. 4.82%). The second weight loss (exp. 5.65%) in the range of 150-220 °C is ascribed to the loss of six coordinated H2O molecules (calcd. 5.78%). However, when the temperature exceeds 300 °C, a large weight loss appears, indicating that the framework has collapsed. According to the TGA result, Mn-PBA samples in our case were calcined at 500 °C by one-step thermal treatment under a flow of air to ensure the complete conversion of precursors to the final products.

elements.content: XRD analysis in a confirmed that the obtained product after pyrolysis was composed of tetragonal Mn3O4 phase (JCPDS No. 24-0734, space group: I41/amd), indicating the successful synthesis of Mn3O4 samples. The Raman spectrum in b shows that two wide peaks at 1598 and 1356 cm–1 result from G (ordered sp2 bonded carbon) and D (disorder or defects of carbon) bands of carbon, respectively. The I G/I D value of the Mn3O4/C sample is 1.19, indicating that the carbon in Mn3O4/C material has a high graphitization degree. The strong peak at 655 cm–1 and a weak peak at 363 cm–1 can be attributed to Mn3O4.
elements.clean_text:
Characterization of the Mn3O4/C Composites

XRD analysis in a confirmed that the obtained product after pyrolysis was composed of tetragonal Mn3O4 phase (JCPDS No. 24-0734, space group: I41/amd), indicating the successful synthesis of Mn3O4 samples. The Raman spectrum in b shows that two wide peaks at 1598 and 1356 cm-1 result from G (ordered sp2 bonded carbon) and D (disorder or defects of carbon) bands of carbon, respectively. The I G/I D value of the Mn3O4/C sample is 1.19, indicating that the carbon in Mn3O4/C material has a high graphitization degree. The strong peak at 655 cm-1 and a weak peak at 363 cm-1 can be attributed to Mn3O4.

elements.content: PXRD pattern (a) and Raman spectrum (b) of Mn3O4/C samples.
elements.clean_text: 2  PXRD pattern (a) and Raman spectrum (b) of Mn3O4/C samples.

elements.content: To study the chemical bonding state and chemical composition of the Mn3O4/C samples, X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was applied. a shows an overall XPS curve of the Mn3O4/C composites, suggesting that the samples are composed of O, C, and Mn elements. b displays the high-resolution XPS spectrum of Mn 2p, where two peaks located at 653.3 and 641.7 eV can be attributed to Mn 2p1/2 and Mn 2p3/2 levels, respectively. The C 1s spectrum in c include three peaks, corresponding to different chemical states of carbon: 288.6 eV (CO), 285.7 eV (C-O), and 284.7 eV (C-C). The O 1s spectrum consists of three binding energy peaks locating at 532.6, 531.3, and 530.0 eV (d). The porous nature of the as-synthesized Mn3O4/C samples was measured by the N2 adsorption–desorption characterization. As depicted in e, it presents a representative type-IV with the hysteresis loops at a high relative pressure between 0.7 and 1.0, implying the mesoporous characteristic with void spaces in the microspheres, which is further confirmed by TEM images (Figures S7 and S11b). The corresponding Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) surface area is calculated to be 137 m2 g–1 with a total pore volume of 0.48 cm3 g–1. The pore-size distribution calculated by the Barrett–Joyner–Halenda (BJH) method suggests the existence of three kinds of mesopores with an average size of 5, 17, and 40 nm. Such high surface areas can reduce volumetric expansion and facilitate the electrolyte diffusion during the long-term cycles, which will be favorable for improving the cycling stability during the charge/discharge process.
elements.clean_text: To study the chemical bonding state and chemical composition of the Mn3O4/C samples, X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was applied. a shows an overall XPS curve of the Mn3O4/C composites, suggesting that the samples are composed of O, C, and Mn elements. b displays the high-resolution XPS spectrum of Mn 2p, where two peaks located at 653.3 and 641.7 eV can be attributed to Mn 2p1/2 and Mn 2p3/2 levels, respectively. The C 1s spectrum in c include three peaks, corresponding to different chemical states of carbon: 288.6 eV (CO), 285.7 eV (C-O), and 284.7 eV (C-C). The O 1s spectrum consists of three binding energy peaks locating at 532.6, 531.3, and 530.0 eV (d). The porous nature of the as-synthesized Mn3O4/C samples was measured by the N2 adsorption-desorption characterization. As depicted in e, it presents a representative type-IV with the hysteresis loops at a high relative pressure between 0.7 and 1.0, implying the mesoporous characteristic with void spaces in the microspheres, which is further confirmed by TEM images (Figures S7 and S11b). The corresponding Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) surface area is calculated to be 137 m2 g-1 with a total pore volume of 0.48 cm3 g-1. The pore-size distribution calculated by the Barrett-Joyner-Halenda (BJH) method suggests the existence of three kinds of mesopores with an average size of 5, 17, and 40 nm. Such high surface areas can reduce volumetric expansion and facilitate the electrolyte diffusion during the long-term cycles, which will be favorable for improving the cycling stability during the charge/discharge process.

elements.content: XPS spectra of Mn3O4/C sample. (a) Survey curve. (b) Mn 2p, (c) C 1s, and (d) O 1s spectra. (e) N2 adsorption/desorption isotherm of Mn3O4/C sample. (f) Pore size distribution.
elements.clean_text: 3  XPS spectra of Mn3O4/C sample. (a) Survey curve. (b) Mn 2p, (c) C 1s, and (d) O 1s spectra. (e) N2 adsorption/desorption isotherm of Mn3O4/C sample. (f) Pore size distribution.

elements.content: In order to better observe the morphology and architecture of the final Mn3O4/C composite, scanning electron microscopy was applied. Compared to the block shape of the Mn-PBA precursor, the shape of Mn3O4/C became microspheres, while the size slightly shrinks ranging from 25 to 5 μm due to the decomposition and volume contraction after calcination (b–d). Additionally, element mapping images further reveal the existence of C, O, and Mn elements in the structure (e–g), which is consistent with the XPS analysis.
elements.clean_text: In order to better observe the morphology and architecture of the final Mn3O4/C composite, scanning electron microscopy was applied. Compared to the block shape of the Mn-PBA precursor, the shape of Mn3O4/C became microspheres, while the size slightly shrinks ranging from 25 to 5 μm due to the decomposition and volume contraction after calcination (b-d). Additionally, element mapping images further reveal the existence of C, O, and Mn elements in the structure (e-g), which is consistent with the XPS analysis.

elements.content: (a) Optical image of Mn-PBA precursors. (b–d) SEM images and (e–g) mapping images of the Mn3O4/C sample.
elements.clean_text: 4  (a) Optical image of Mn-PBA precursors. (b-d) SEM images and (e-g) mapping images of the Mn3O4/C sample.

elements.content: The electrochemical properties of the as-synthesized Mn3O4/C composites were systematically studied. Cyclic voltammetric (CV) curves of the Mn3O4/C electrode were tested for the first three cycles with a scan rate of 0.1 mV s–1. As shown in a, a reduction peak at 0.79 V in the first cathodic sweep was observed due to the reduction of Mn3+ to Mn2+ (Mn3O4 + 2Li+ + 2e– → 3MnO + Li2O) and the generation of a solid electrolyte interface (SEI) layer. This peak disappears in the following cycle. The reduction peak appeared at 0.21 V, which shifted to about 0.43 V in the second cycle, involving the formation of Li2O and manganese metal (MnO + 2Li+ + 2e– → Mn + Li2O). In the anodic scan performance, the oxidation peak appeared at 1.18 V due to the oxidation reaction of Mn0 to Mn2+/Mn3+ and Li2O decomposition (3Mn + 8Li2O → Mn3O4 + 8Li+ + 8e–), which remained in the further cycles. The overlapping curves were observed from the second cycle, demonstrating good reversibility and structural stability of the electrode. b presents the galvanostatical charge/discharge at 200 mA g–1 within the range of 0.01–3.0 V. The first charge and discharge capacities are 1205 and 1500 mAh g–1, respectively. The corresponding Coulombic efficiency is 80.3%. The loss of capacity in the first cycle might be due to the irreversible electrochemical reactions, such as the inevitable formation of the SEI layer and decomposition of the electrolyte. Despite the initial capacity loss, the charge–discharge profiles are basically invariable without capacity fading from the subsequent cycles. c presents the cycling performance at different densities of 0.2, 1, and 1.5 A g–1, respectively. Apparently, the capacity of the electrode under all conditions was stabilized and Coulombic efficiency maintained almost 100% after the initial cycle. Especially, a reversible capacity of 1032 mAh g–1 was still retained after 500 cycles at 0.2 A g–1, which confirms the reusability of the Mn3O4/C composite electrode. This observed specific capacity is higher than the theoretical value of Mn3O4 (937 mAh g–1) and other Mn3O4 hybrid anode materials reported previously (Table S3). Moreover, in comparison with the only example of MOFs-derived porous Mn3O4 materials, our Mn3O4/C electrode shows much higher reversible capacity and a more superior rate capacity. Additionally, we also observe the electrochemical behavior of pure carbon material by using Mn-PBA as precursor. The PXRD pattern shows two characteristic peaks at 24° and 43° (Figure S8), indicating the successful synthesis of carbon material. As depicted in Figure S9, the carbon electrode exhibits a discharge capacity of 516 mAh g–1, which is higher than the theoretical capacity of commercial graphite material. We believe that the advantage of structural and compositional features contribute to the improvement of capacity.
elements.clean_text:
Electrochemical Performances

The electrochemical properties of the as-synthesized Mn3O4/C composites were systematically studied. Cyclic voltammetric (CV) curves of the Mn3O4/C electrode were tested for the first three cycles with a scan rate of 0.1 mV s-1. As shown in a, a reduction peak at 0.79 V in the first cathodic sweep was observed due to the reduction of Mn3+ to Mn2+ (Mn3O4 + 2Li+ + 2e- → 3MnO + Li2O) and the generation of a solid electrolyte interface (SEI) layer. This peak disappears in the following cycle. The reduction peak appeared at 0.21 V, which shifted to about 0.43 V in the second cycle, involving the formation of Li2O and manganese metal (MnO + 2Li+ + 2e- → Mn + Li2O). In the anodic scan performance, the oxidation peak appeared at 1.18 V due to the oxidation reaction of Mn0 to Mn2+/Mn3+ and Li2O decomposition (3Mn + 8Li2O → Mn3O4 + 8Li+ + 8e-), which remained in the further cycles. The overlapping curves were observed from the second cycle, demonstrating good reversibility and structural stability of the electrode. b presents the galvanostatical charge/discharge at 200 mA g-1 within the range of 0.01-3.0 V. The first charge and discharge capacities are 1205 and 1500 mAh g-1, respectively. The corresponding Coulombic efficiency is 80.3%. The loss of capacity in the first cycle might be due to the irreversible electrochemical reactions, such as the inevitable formation of the SEI layer and decomposition of the electrolyte. Despite the initial capacity loss, the charge-discharge profiles are basically invariable without capacity fading from the subsequent cycles. c presents the cycling performance at different densities of 0.2, 1, and 1.5 A g-1, respectively. Apparently, the capacity of the electrode under all conditions was stabilized and Coulombic efficiency maintained almost 100% after the initial cycle. Especially, a reversible capacity of 1032 mAh g-1 was still retained after 500 cycles at 0.2 A g-1, which confirms the reusability of the Mn3O4/C composite electrode. This observed specific capacity is higher than the theoretical value of Mn3O4 (937 mAh g-1) and other Mn3O4 hybrid anode materials reported previously (Table S3). Moreover, in comparison with the only example of MOFs-derived porous Mn3O4 materials, our Mn3O4/C electrode shows much higher reversible capacity and a more superior rate capacity. Additionally, we also observe the electrochemical behavior of pure carbon material by using Mn-PBA as precursor. The PXRD pattern shows two characteristic peaks at 24° and 43° (Figure S8), indicating the successful synthesis of carbon material. As depicted in Figure S9, the carbon electrode exhibits a discharge capacity of 516 mAh g-1, which is higher than the theoretical capacity of commercial graphite material. We believe that the advantage of structural and compositional features contribute to the improvement of capacity.

elements.content: Electrochemical performance of Mn3O4/C electrode measured at room temperature (25 °C). (a) Cyclic voltammetry tests. (b) Discharge–charge curves of Mn3O4/C at 200 mA g–1. (c) Coulombic efficiency and cycling performance at various current densities of 0.2, 1, and 1.5 A g–1. (d) Nyquist plots of the Mn3O4/C electrode before and after cycles with the proposed equivalent circuit.
elements.clean_text: 5  Electrochemical performance of Mn3O4/C electrode measured at room temperature (25 °C). (a) Cyclic voltammetry tests. (b) Discharge-charge curves of Mn3O4/C at 200 mA g-1. (c) Coulombic efficiency and cycling performance at various current densities of 0.2, 1, and 1.5 A g-1. (d) Nyquist plots of the Mn3O4/C electrode before and after cycles with the proposed equivalent circuit.

elements.content: To get further insight into electrochemical performance, electrochemical impedance spectra (EIS) of Mn3O4/C after 500 cycles were also investigated (d). All Nyquist curves consist of a semicircle (high-frequency region) related to the charge-transfer resistance (R ct) and an inclined line (low-frequency) indexed to the diffusion rate of lithium ion. The value of R ct is smaller for the Mn3O4/C electrode after the 500th cycle than that before cycling (before cycling: 59.94 Ω; after cycling: 48.98 Ω), indicating the fast charge transport during the lithium intercalation/deintercalation process. Moreover, the XRD pattern of the electrode after 500 cycles reveals that most peak positions are similar to that before cycles (Figure S10), indicating structure stability of the electrode during the charge/discharge process, which is further confirmed by SEM and TEM images (Figure S11). Meanwhile, the N2 adsorption–desorption curve in Figure S12 reveals that the mesoporous feature is still maintained while the BET surface area decreases to 86 m2 g–1, indicating part of the pores are blocked during the lithium storage process.
elements.clean_text: To get further insight into electrochemical performance, electrochemical impedance spectra (EIS) of Mn3O4/C after 500 cycles were also investigated (d). All Nyquist curves consist of a semicircle (high-frequency region) related to the charge-transfer resistance (R ct) and an inclined line (low-frequency) indexed to the diffusion rate of lithium ion. The value of R ct is smaller for the Mn3O4/C electrode after the 500th cycle than that before cycling (before cycling: 59.94 Ω; after cycling: 48.98 Ω), indicating the fast charge transport during the lithium intercalation/deintercalation process. Moreover, the XRD pattern of the electrode after 500 cycles reveals that most peak positions are similar to that before cycles (Figure S10), indicating structure stability of the electrode during the charge/discharge process, which is further confirmed by SEM and TEM images (Figure S11). Meanwhile, the N2 adsorption-desorption curve in Figure S12 reveals that the mesoporous feature is still maintained while the BET surface area decreases to 86 m2 g-1, indicating part of the pores are blocked during the lithium storage process.

elements.content: Generally speaking, the annealing temperature is a crucial factor to get desired materials when using MOFs as precursors. To evaluate the effect of decomposition temperature, comparative experiments were performed by changing the annealing temperature at 600 and 700 °C. The obtained corresponding porous Mn3O4/C composites were designated as Mn3O4/C-600 and Mn3O4/C-700, respectively. Apparently, both of the PXRD patterns confirm the tetragonal Mn3O4 phase after the thermal transformation process (Figure S13), which is similar to that of Mn3O4/C-500. It can be clearly found that the Mn3O4/C-500 electrode displays much better cycling performance than those of the Mn3O4/C-600 and Mn3O4/C-700 electrodes (Figure S14). As depicted from the SEM images (Figure S15), some agglomerates are observed at 600 °C. At a higher temperature of 700 °C, the initial morphology was found to collapse and nonregular shapes were generated. In addition, a displays the rate performance of the Mn3O4/C-500 electrode under different current densities. Corresponding discharge capacities at 0.2, 0.5, 1, and 2 A g–1 are 1032, 946, 848, and 695 mAh g–1, respectively. Especially, the capacity can recover back to the similar value as the original one when it returns to 0.2 A g–1, demonstrating the excellent electrochemical reversibility. However, Mn3O4/C-600 and Mn3O4/C-700 samples display much lower capacities of only 598 and 482 mAh g–1 at the high current of 2 A g–1. Meanwhile, the capacity of these two samples drops quickly. Besides, the impedance related to the R ct in Mn3O4/C-500 is lower than that of the Mn3O4/C-600 and Mn3O4/C-700 (b), demonstrating the superior conductive capability of the electrode. This result also explains the better electrochemical property of the Mn3O4/C-500 electrode.

To evaluate the effect of decomposition temperature, comparative experiments were performed by changing the annealing temperature at 600 and 700 °C. The obtained corresponding porous Mn3O4/C composites were designated as Mn3O4/C-600 and Mn3O4/C-700, respectively. Apparently, both of the PXRD patterns confirm the tetragonal Mn3O4 phase after the thermal transformation process (Figure S13), which is similar to that of Mn3O4/C-500. It can be clearly found that the Mn3O4/C-500 electrode displays much better cycling performance than those of the Mn3O4/C-600 and Mn3O4/C-700 electrodes (Figure S14). As depicted from the SEM images (Figure S15), some agglomerates are observed at 600 °C. At a higher temperature of 700 °C, the initial morphology was found to collapse and nonregular shapes were generated. In addition, a displays the rate performance of the Mn3O4/C-500 electrode under different current densities. Corresponding discharge capacities at 0.2, 0.5, 1, and 2 A g-1 are 1032, 946, 848, and 695 mAh g-1, respectively. Especially, the capacity can recover back to the similar value as the original one when it returns to 0.2 A g-1, demonstrating the excellent electrochemical reversibility. However, Mn3O4/C-600 and Mn3O4/C-700 samples display much lower capacities of only 598 and 482 mAh g-1 at the high current of 2 A g-1. Meanwhile, the capacity of these two samples drops quickly. Besides, the impedance related to the R ct in Mn3O4/C-500 is lower than that of the Mn3O4/C-600 and Mn3O4/C-700 (b), demonstrating the superior conductive capability of the electrode. This result also explains the better electrochemical property of the Mn3O4/C-500 electrode.

elements.content: Mn3O4/C-500, Mn3O4/C-600, and Mn3O4/C-700 electrodes. (a) Rate capability at various current densities. The initial five discharge capacities were omitted. (b) Nyquist plots before cycles.
elements.clean_text: 6  Mn3O4/C-500, Mn3O4/C-600, and Mn3O4/C-700 electrodes. (a) Rate capability at various current densities. The initial five discharge capacities were omitted. (b) Nyquist plots before cycles.

elements.content: In summary, a mesoporous Mn3O4/C microsphere was successfully fabricated via one-step calcination of Mn-PBA as templates under an air atmosphere. The resultant Mn3O4/C electrode exhibited high reversible specific capacity (1032 mAh g–1 at 0.2 A g–1) together with stable cycling behavior and good rate performance. The improved lithium storage is supposed to benefit from the unique microspheres and large accessible specific area. The remarkable performances make it a promising anode material for LIBs.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

In summary, a mesoporous Mn3O4/C microsphere was successfully fabricated via one-step calcination of Mn-PBA as templates under an air atmosphere. The resultant Mn3O4/C electrode exhibited high reversible specific capacity (1032 mAh g-1 at 0.2 A g-1) together with stable cycling behavior and good rate performance. The improved lithium storage is supposed to benefit from the unique microspheres and large accessible specific area. The remarkable performances make it a promising anode material for LIBs.

cln_elements.content: The synthetic route of the H2PBA ligand is given in Figure S1, and the obtained ligand was further confirmed by H1 NMR spectrum (Figure S2). A mixture containing H2PBA (72.4 mg, 0.2 mmol), Mn­(NO3)2·6H2O (112 mg, 0.4 mmol), H2O (12 mL), and dimethylformamide (12 mL) was sealed in a glass reaction bottle. The system was heated at 100 °C for 3 days and then cooled to room temperature. Pale yellow crystals were obtained by filtration and washed with DMF. FT-IR (KBr, cm–1): 3266 (m), 2373 (w), 2036 (w), 1616 (vs), 1548 (w), 1394 (w), 904 (w), 617 (vs) (see Figure S3). Anal. Calcd for C80H78­N8O31Mn4 (1867.26): C 51.49, H 4.18, N 5.99%; found: C 51.43, H 4.22, N 5.97%.
cln_elements.clean_text:
Preparation of the Mn-PBA

The synthetic route of the H2PBA ligand is given in Figure S1, and the obtained ligand was further confirmed by H1 NMR spectrum (Figure S2). A mixture containing H2PBA (72.4 mg, 0.2 mmol), Mn(NO3)2⋅6H2O (112 mg, 0.4 mmol), H2O (12 mL), and dimethylformamide (12 mL) was sealed in a glass reaction bottle. The system was heated at 100 °C for 3 days and then cooled to room temperature. Pale yellow crystals were obtained by filtration and washed with DMF. FT-IR (KBr, cm-1): 3266 (m), 2373 (w), 2036 (w), 1616 (vs), 1548 (w), 1394 (w), 904 (w), 617 (vs) (see Figure S3). Anal. Calcd for C80H78N8O31Mn4 (1867.26): C 51.49, H 4.18, N 5.99%; found: C 51.43, H 4.22, N 5.97%.

cln_elements.content:
Mesoporous Mn3O4/C micropheres were obtained by thermolysis of a Mn-PBA MOF as precursor under an air atmosphere and used as LIBs anode material. The results display that the Mn3O4/C electrode shows a high capacity of about 1032 mAh g−1 at 0.2 A g−1 after 500 cycles, together with the stable cycling behavior and good rate performance.

The power X-ray diffraction (PXRD) pattern of the as-prepared Mn-PBA is shown in Figure S4. Most of the peak positions in the as-made samples and simulated one are quite well matched, indicating phase purity of the bulk samples. The difference in diffraction intensity may be due to the preferred orientation effect of the powder particles. The infrared spectrum (IR) reveals the adsorption peak around 3266 cm–1 for Mn-PBA assigned to the v­(OH) vibrations of the H2O molecules. Strong peaks at 1616 and 1393 cm–1 corresponded to asymmetric and symmetric vibrations for carboxylate groups (Figure S5). Thermal stability of the Mn-PBA was also measured under an air atmosphere. The curve in Figure S6 shows three main mass losses. The first weight loss (exp. 4.86%) between 30 and 150 °C corresponds to the release of five free H2O molecules (calcd. 4.82%). The second weight loss (exp. 5.65%) in the range of 150–220 °C is ascribed to the loss of six coordinated H2O molecules (calcd. 5.78%). However, when the temperature exceeds 300 °C, a large weight loss appears, indicating that the framework has collapsed. According to the TGA result, Mn-PBA samples in our case were calcined at 500 °C by one-step thermal treatment under a flow of air to ensure the complete conversion of precursors to the final products.

To study the chemical bonding state and chemical composition of the Mn3O4/C samples, X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was applied. a shows an overall XPS curve of the Mn3O4/C composites, suggesting that the samples are composed of O, C, and Mn elements. b displays the high-resolution XPS spectrum of Mn 2p, where two peaks located at 653.3 and 641.7 eV can be attributed to Mn 2p1/2 and Mn 2p3/2 levels, respectively. The C 1s spectrum in c include three peaks, corresponding to different chemical states of carbon: 288.6 eV (CO), 285.7 eV (C-O), and 284.7 eV (C-C). The O 1s spectrum consists of three binding energy peaks locating at 532.6, 531.3, and 530.0 eV (d). The porous nature of the as-synthesized Mn3O4/C samples was measured by the N2 adsorption–desorption characterization. As depicted in e, it presents a representative type-IV with the hysteresis loops at a high relative pressure between 0.7 and 1.0, implying the mesoporous characteristic with void spaces in the microspheres, which is further confirmed by TEM images (Figures S7 and S11b). The corresponding Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) surface area is calculated to be 137 m2 g–1 with a total pore volume of 0.48 cm3 g–1. The pore-size distribution calculated by the Barrett–Joyner–Halenda (BJH) method suggests the existence of three kinds of mesopores with an average size of 5, 17, and 40 nm. Such high surface areas can reduce volumetric expansion and facilitate the electrolyte diffusion during the long-term cycles, which will be favorable for improving the cycling stability during the charge/discharge process.

Electrochemical Performances

The electrochemical properties of the as-synthesized Mn3O4/C composites were systematically studied. Cyclic voltammetric (CV) curves of the Mn3O4/C electrode were tested for the first three cycles with a scan rate of 0.1 mV s–1. As shown in a, a reduction peak at 0.79 V in the first cathodic sweep was observed due to the reduction of Mn3+ to Mn2+ (Mn3O4 + 2Li+ + 2e– → 3MnO + Li2O) and the generation of a solid electrolyte interface (SEI) layer. This peak disappears in the following cycle. The reduction peak appeared at 0.21 V, which shifted to about 0.43 V in the second cycle, involving the formation of Li2O and manganese metal (MnO + 2Li+ + 2e– → Mn + Li2O). In the anodic scan performance, the oxidation peak appeared at 1.18 V due to the oxidation reaction of Mn0 to Mn2+/Mn3+ and Li2O decomposition (3Mn + 8Li2O → Mn3O4 + 8Li+ + 8e–), which remained in the further cycles. The overlapping curves were observed from the second cycle, demonstrating good reversibility and structural stability of the electrode. b presents the galvanostatical charge/discharge at 200 mA g–1 within the range of 0.01–3.0 V. The first charge and discharge capacities are 1205 and 1500 mAh g–1, respectively. The corresponding Coulombic efficiency is 80.3%. The loss of capacity in the first cycle might be due to the irreversible electrochemical reactions, such as the inevitable formation of the SEI layer and decomposition of the electrolyte. Despite the initial capacity loss, the charge–discharge profiles are basically invariable without capacity fading from the subsequent cycles. c presents the cycling performance at different densities of 0.2, 1, and 1.5 A g–1, respectively. Apparently, the capacity of the electrode under all conditions was stabilized and Coulombic efficiency maintained almost 100% after the initial cycle. Especially, a reversible capacity of 1032 mAh g–1 was still retained after 500 cycles at 0.2 A g–1, which confirms the reusability of the Mn3O4/C composite electrode. This observed specific capacity is higher than the theoretical value of Mn3O4 (937 mAh g–1) and other Mn3O4 hybrid anode materials reported previously (Table S3). Moreover, in comparison with the only example of MOFs-derived porous Mn3O4 materials, our Mn3O4/C electrode shows much higher reversible capacity and a more superior rate capacity. Additionally, we also observe the electrochemical behavior of pure carbon material by using Mn-PBA as precursor. The PXRD pattern shows two characteristic peaks at 24° and 43° (Figure S8), indicating the successful synthesis of carbon material. As depicted in Figure S9, the carbon electrode exhibits a discharge capacity of 516 mAh g–1, which is higher than the theoretical capacity of commercial graphite material. We believe that the advantage of structural and compositional features contribute to the improvement of capacity.

Conclusion

In summary, a mesoporous Mn3O4/C microsphere was successfully fabricated via one-step calcination of Mn-PBA as templates under an air atmosphere. The resultant Mn3O4/C electrode exhibited high reversible specific capacity (1032 mAh g–1 at 0.2 A g–1) together with stable cycling behavior and good rate performance. The improved lithium storage is supposed to benefit from the unique microspheres and large accessible specific area. The remarkable performances make it a promising anode material for LIBs.

cln_elements.content: XPS spectra of Mn3O4/C sample. (a) Survey curve. (b) Mn 2p, (c) C 1s, and (d) O 1s spectra. (e) N2 adsorption/desorption isotherm of Mn3O4/C sample. (f) Pore size distribution.
cln_elements.clean_text: 3  XPS spectra of Mn3O4/C sample. (a) Survey curve. (b) Mn 2p, (c) C 1s, and (d) O 1s spectra. (e) N2 adsorption/desorption isotherm of Mn3O4/C sample. (f) Pore size distribution.

cln_elements.content: (a) Optical image of Mn-PBA precursors. (b–d) SEM images and (e–g) mapping images of the Mn3O4/C sample.
cln_elements.clean_text: 4  (a) Optical image of Mn-PBA precursors. (b-d) SEM images and (e-g) mapping images of the Mn3O4/C sample.

cln_elements.content: Electrochemical performance of Mn3O4/C electrode measured at room temperature (25 °C). (a) Cyclic voltammetry tests. (b) Discharge–charge curves of Mn3O4/C at 200 mA g–1. (c) Coulombic efficiency and cycling performance at various current densities of 0.2, 1, and 1.5 A g–1. (d) Nyquist plots of the Mn3O4/C electrode before and after cycles with the proposed equivalent circuit.
cln_elements.clean_text: 5  Electrochemical performance of Mn3O4/C electrode measured at room temperature (25 °C). (a) Cyclic voltammetry tests. (b) Discharge-charge curves of Mn3O4/C at 200 mA g-1. (c) Coulombic efficiency and cycling performance at various current densities of 0.2, 1, and 1.5 A g-1. (d) Nyquist plots of the Mn3O4/C electrode before and after cycles with the proposed equivalent circuit.

cln_elements.content: Mn3O4/C-500, Mn3O4/C-600, and Mn3O4/C-700 electrodes. (a) Rate capability at various current densities. The initial five discharge capacities were omitted. (b) Nyquist plots before cycles.

metadata.title:
